A non-displaced fracture is identified through the right femoral neck with surrounding sclerosis suggesting chronicity of approximately 2-3 weeks. The left hip appears intact with no acute fracture. No significant joint effusion. Mild degenerative changes noted at both sacroiliac joints. Soft tissue calcification noted in the right gluteal region, likely vascular in nature. The visualised lower lumbar spine demonstrates reduced bone density with compression deformity of L4 vertebral body. Orthopaedic review recommended for management of femoral neck fracture.

Dr Sarah Mitchell, Consultant Radiologist 15/07/2025, 16:45
"""

The report explicitly mentions generalised osteopenia and reduced bone density, consistent with metabolic bone disease. The presence of a non-displaced femoral neck fracture, a common site for pathological fractures in osteoporosis, along with a compression deformity of L4, further supports this. """
18/07/2025, 09:30, CT THORAX WITH CONTRAST

Case History:

Reason for Request: Discussion in MDT regarding Lung Pathology

Findings: ASD and VSD noted, with markedly dilated right atrium. Pulmonary veins are broadly patent. The lungs are of large volume. There are bands of atelectasis in both lower lobes. There is slight hyperlucency of the left lung apex with slight rightward displacement of the anterior junction line suggesting some localised overinflation. The central airways are patent. No lung cysts. There is a healing fracture of the posterolateral aspect of the right 9th rib. Subtle callus formation is probably visible on chest radiograph dated 16/07/2025, but not on prior radiographs.

Conclusion:

Large volume lungs with some atelectasis, some focal hyperinflation in left upper lobe. Findings may reflect infection eg bronchiolitis, but in the context aspiration may also be considered. Incidentally demonstrated healing fracture of the right 9th posterolateral rib. This was demonstrable in retrospect on the radiograph dated 16/07/2025 but not prior. It is unlikely this fracture was sustained more than 10 days prior to the last radiograph where fracture not visible (13th July), ie not before 3rd July, and therefore likely sustained during the current admission. Alert raised for incidental rib fracture.

--------------
HOSPITAL ALERT This imaging examination has an UNEXPECTED FINDING and needs your review. REVIEW THE IMAGE AND REPORT and take any ACTION necessary. You can then CLICK Done, Acknowledge or Mark as Reviewed.
-------------

Dr James Harrison, Consultant Radiologist 18/07/2025, 10:15 GMC 5873421

The patient was scanned using a vacuum immobilisation bag due to motion concerns. This results in a linear artefact in the anteroposterior direction, most evident at the level of the corona radiata and posterior fossa, limiting assessment in these regions -Within the above limitation, no evidence of acute intracranial haemorrhage or established territorial infarction. -No midline shift or signs of transtentorial or uncal herniation. -The foramen magnum is capacious, with no tonsillar herniation. -No acute calvarial fracture is identified. -Ventricular size and configuration are within normal limits. -No hydrocephalus or sulcal effacement.

Opinion: No acute intracranial haemorrhage, infarction, or herniation identified within the limitations of linear artefact from the immobilisation bag. No acute calvarial fracture.

Dr Oliver Matthews, Radiology Registrar ST4 Approved by Dr Rachel Patel, Consultant Neuroradiologist GMC-8126745 19/10/2025, 15:52
"""

No significant joint effusion. Mild degenerative changes noted at both sacroiliac joints. Soft tissue calcification noted in the right gluteal region, likely vascular in nature. The visualised lower lumbar spine demonstrates reduced bone density with compression deformity of L4 vertebral body. Orthopaedic review recommended for management of femoral neck fracture.

Dr Sarah Mitchell, Consultant Radiologist 15/07/2025, 16:45
"""

The report explicitly mentions generalised osteopenia and reduced bone density, consistent with metabolic bone disease. The surrounding sclerosis suggests chronicity, which can be seen in stress fractures or insufficiency fractures (pathological). Contradicting evidence: None identified. The fracture occurred after a minor fall, which is characteristic of pathological fractures in patients with weakened bones. Final diagnosis: Confirmed pathological fracture.

Radiology report:
"""
18/07/2025, 09:30, CT THORAX WITH CONTRAST

Case History:

Reason for Request: Discussion in MDT regarding Lung Pathology

Findings: ASD and VSD noted, with markedly dilated right atrium. Pulmonary veins are broadly patent. The lungs are of large volume. There are bands of atelectasis in both lower lobes. There is slight hyperlucency of the left lung apex with slight rightward displacement of the anterior junction line suggesting some localised overinflation. The central airways are patent. No lung cysts. There is a healing fracture of the posterolateral aspect of the right 9th rib. Subtle callus formation is probably visible on chest radiograph dated 16/07/2025, but not on prior radiographs.

Conclusion:

Large volume lungs with some atelectasis, some focal hyperinflation in left upper lobe. Findings may reflect infection eg bronchiolitis, but in the context aspiration may also be considered. Incidentally demonstrated healing fracture of the right 9th posterolateral rib. This was demonstrable in retrospect on the radiograph dated 16/07/2025 but not prior. It is unlikely this fracture was sustained more than 10 days prior to the last radiograph where fracture not visible (13th July), ie not before 3rd July, and therefore likely sustained during the current admission. Alert raised for incidental rib fracture.

--------------
HOSPITAL ALERT This imaging examination has an UNEXPECTED FINDING and needs your review. REVIEW THE IMAGE AND REPORT and take any ACTION necessary. You can then CLICK Done, Acknowledge or Mark as Reviewed.
-------------

Dr James Harrison, Consultant Radiologist 18/07/2025, 10:15 GMC 5873421
"""

Response:
